761C50F4ACE44B63911403AFEFCCAB12.description: Compare traditional and contemporary arts expressions from specific cultural groups (e.g., traditional Francophone music compared to contemporary Francophone music).

9ADCEA669A4B4819BDCE500B517406BA.description: Use the Internet, and other sources such as community resource people, to help identify, discuss, and analyze traditional and contemporary arts expressions from specific cultural groups.

6AAAA749370B4F4B8BC3A5866F0D9BD2.description: View and listen to a range of traditional and contemporary arts expressions from around the world.

8144F8EFC6094F4895EF8B0E995D689B.description: Investigate arts expressions from a range of cultures and countries, and analyze how cultural identity is reflected in the work.

9EFFAA3AED434E17858A2011E2F0B7AA.description: Engage in research (e.g., interviewing a group of women contemporary fancy dancers) to deepen understanding of how cultural identity is expressed in contemporary work.

985C6587B85341C8AE9D2D5B2045230B.description: Make connections between traditional expressions of cultural identity (e.g., throat singing, quill work) and the ideas of contemporary artists.

006CFAA3880249B2BCAE9414974AF611.description: Analyze and discuss how artists reflect cultural identity in their work.

1FDA9249B8124063B27DBE3807802063.description: Observe, listen to, and inquire about the traditional protocols that may affect contemporary arts expressions (e.g., What do Saulteaux Elders think about the inclusion of sacred aspects of culture such as painting on tipis by contemporary artists?).

DF1519F499D8453AAD09A9F8F812072E.description: Formulate questions and conduct an inquiry to discover how the work of various contemporary First Nations, Métis, and Inuit dance, drama, music, and visual artists expresses cultural identity.

DF0D67484CBE474D9ADB86C41D679CCB.description: Identify ways that First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artists express cultural identity in contemporary work.

1778A8716F4F45CDA4F501EA9EAFBBEB.description: Describe why personal and cultural identity is often an important influence in the creation of arts expressions.

DB8070F9B9F142F48A3244A1CD8D5804.description: Use inquiry and share findings about professional artists in Saskatchewan, examining their expressions and various identities.

2877BD4537B74193AC88FE498107FCB7.description: Participate, when possible, in partnerships with Saskatchewan artists and arts organizations to increase understanding of arts content and practices, and to understand how identity may be expressed in various art forms

E1FF473B70D744AB9A7B665181F5FDB4.description: Apply critical thinking when analyzing and describing how identity is expressed in arts expressions (e.g., hip hop, blues, country music).

28941E63F3AB4E93BBFE702BE7C00A6B.description: Investigate how personal, cultural, or regional identity may be reflected in arts expressions.

57E2F21090EA48DDABD08DEDB560A26A.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) - Children will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and understand the connection between the arts and human experience.

D1A4AB6C752B4922AB6901331B8FF75C.description: Discuss personal characteristics and career requirements of professional artists (e.g., self-discipline, passion, postsecondary education, contract and seasonal work, independent learners, entrepreneurial and grant writing abilities).

52D4D50FBA004525B1731C3FB6627FA9.description: Consider informed opinions and worldviews that differ from their own.

6DC3EF26273F4964AF7266FDD64B3081.description: Demonstrate open-mindedness when responding to arts expressions.

C03A58C6645340BCACB4F2ABDD34536B.description: Describe the many contributions artists make to community life (e.g., research and interview local artists).

2205F7FBD9D24B479F78C56E466383F8.description: Support opinions about arts expressions with evidence found in the work and further study

3B5DE7D41B744905A48B932BC93F75A0.description: Interpret and evaluate art works in an informed manner, and expand arts vocabulary

A6858D22F43C45DDAB220D07391B1F31.description: Describe, analyze, interpret, and draw conclusions about the content and aesthetics of various arts expressions.

47FB4BE7C671482FAB65C5B302869F10.description: Examine arts expressions and artists of various times and places.

448DCE99D02C4D9D9568E1CC33575DB3.description: Demonstrate awareness that artists are curious about their world and explore significant questions and concepts such as identity.

B133894581324E87A9997662D91E83B3.description: Reflect on and discuss the intentions, problem-solving processes, and interpretations of own and others’ arts expressions including how they relate to the concept of identity

8797C0F4CF144EF890910DFBEE164D85.description: Analyze and describe how identity may be expressed through various styles and forms of art.

2349CE448FEF4C668B13C1FBBE37FA9B.description: Investigate and identify ways that the arts can express ideas about identity.

E65F0B48BCCB49A4A8FD67C7FA308257.description: Describe how personal response and own arts expression connects to the original work.

975933973D2E481B8C22867625CC2199.description: Discuss interpretations of arts expressions and create own expressions in response to the original work

57AD71846CC24907A08861FC9C802C75.description: Recognize that cultural background and experiences affect responses to arts expressions and the understanding of symbols and meanings.

B720DD7D4017488E9E0B70FCF98B429D.description: Demonstrate critical and creative thinking when responding to the work of Saskatchewan and other Canadian dance, drama, music, and visual artists (e.g., composers, graphic artists, architects, actors, filmmakers).

8487F10758F14A79842FE4987F77F7ED.description: Create personal responses to a variety of arts expressions (e.g., respond to music using poetry, or respond to visual art using music).

655BB8FE000C4DDCA30E126204ED379E.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) - Children will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry

B02C496731594267BA0C95B3C5B37674.description: Describe own critical and creative thinking, decision-making, and problem-solving processes.

FCBB94E5B1014248B39961C2A792B119.description: Recognize that decision making and problem solving are essential to the creative process, and apply to own work.

FCBD36490F184B1084296462E806FC15.description: Demonstrate skillful use of a range of appropriate tools, technology, materials, and techniques.

145C106169364A05AB62F223BAC80B33.description: Explore and determine appropriate media, technology, forms, and methods for visual expression.

2A03FD7B897141719B570B2355160142.description: Demonstrate increased skills and problem-solving abilities in a variety of visual art media.

8D749645F5A840AEA4DC36520CB179E9.description: Demonstrate how symbols and other images can be used to convey meaning (e.g., create a visual statement about personal and/or cultural identity).

42157F5692A348BF985C9CD30C1A07EE.description: Use the Internet and other sources (e.g., local artists) to gain information about the use of symbolic imagery and apply to own work.

188547E3CC0C439BB0FB5D39FD74D0F2.description: Observe, interpret, and discuss the use of symbols to represent ideas.

6C18593E28CD4139BE40CEE149C2DA2E.description: Examine ways of creating contrast (e.g., bold/subtle, rough/ smooth, light/dark)

24F5FC5EC5AA40C7AC31B3E628F3A015.description: Make keen observations of detail, and increase skills in representing unique features of individual people, animals, plants, and objects.

648818DFFB3A450BBAE4913259F9788A.description: Investigate how visual artists and popular media manipulate the elements of art (i.e., line, colour, texture, shape, form, and space) and principles of design (e.g., balance, rhythm, emphasis, variety, contrast, proportion/scale) to achieve intentions, and apply understanding to own work.

52FB1808A8834F0D99A80475D3850459.description: Select various visual art forms (e.g., drawing, mixed media sculpture) to express ideas about youth and identity.

C44ECD7E5D6E44AD9B44CA49F2218275.description: Investigate and use various visual art forms, images, and art-making processes to express ideas about identity.

9929E6CEBBCF4071B7750EE2CC0B6FB9.description: Reflect on how images, elements of art, and principles of composition can be organized to convey meaning and express identity in visual art (e.g., What messages or ideas does our art work convey about identity?).

4AC5ED72704D4297A316D107D1CD723E.description: Reflect, analyze, and make connections between the original topic or inquiry question and subsequent visual art explorations.

70D9E2A813964B74B119EDC643DD5734.description: Demonstrate self-awareness in decision making about own choices of media, techniques, and subject matter.

4FEB3A9EA4784BB6AD5A7CA84C547D00.description: Recognize valuable accidents in explorations and put them to use when appropriate.

D8E2045E52B2403D9024F07BB9CC8E2C.description: Investigate how a single idea can be developed in many ways and directions (e.g., How many different ways could we represent visually the idea of individual isolation or exclusion from a peer group?).

43743567B68344FABD65DA65FEC41D61.description: Use inquiry in visual art to extend understanding of identity (e.g., examine how pop culture trends such as clothing design, hair styles, and visual images in mass media influence youth identities): Generate key questions to guide inquiry in visual art (e.g., How could we visually represent the uniqueness and distinguishing attributes of different peer group identities?)., Summarize and focus knowledge of topic to determine information needs., Generate additional relevant questions for deeper exploration., Use the Internet and other sources (e.g., print, digital, community) to gather ideas for visual art., Explore the central questions and ideas visually (e.g., How could we communicate visually that each peer group has a distinct identity but also share common concerns? In what ways do graffiti artists represent their identities? How could this mural or installation represent the diverse identities of students in our school?). and Expand on ideas in reflective records such as visual journals, blogs, and video or audio recordings.

F2048B7AF09E4F95B53847115C8AED10.description: Create visual art works that express ideas about identity and how it is influenced (e.g., factors such as pop culture, cultural heritage, peer groups, personal and family interests, gender).

7DD8CBB523B54C6EA2028B3653258ABB.description: Reflect upon choices made during the composing process.

ECE1E6A4F5B847C695610612707F7C0C.description: Explain how various compositions express identity

2FCF13C280E7414FB3F6CCEAC04AC40F.description: Collaborate on the creation of sound compositions that convey a sense of identity (e.g., country, rock, blues, rave or electronic compositions; hip hop or rap commentaries on youth identity; 50s, 60s, 80s eras; various cultural identities).

FF11D3665B074AE6B37643C9ABDE40D0.description: Use inquiry in music to extend understanding of relationships between music and identity: Generate questions to guide inquiry into ways that adolescents’ identity might be influenced by, or reflected in, different musical styles, Access a broad range of resources (e.g., print, digital, interviews, community) as sources of information, Convey understanding of identity as expressed in own music compositions and/or performances. and Collaborate with peers to document the inquiry and composition process.

7746EB22D6BB4990A8CB691D72360D26.description: Create sound compositions that explore relationships between music and identity (e.g., influencing factors such as pop culture, cultural heritage, peer groups, personal and family interests, gender).

2D38EAE38E68442D87ED12590A7D47FB.description: Use the Internet and other sources (e.g., guest musicians) to identify, analyze, and create repetition and variety in different styles of music.

5F46F694EC2A4272AF2BDD022903EAAF.description: Examine ways that silence can be used in compositions.

D73FD33EEAC14B0CB071C7ABB41B743D.description: Demonstrate and discuss how increase in texture (e.g., the addition of melodic/rhythmic patterns or ostinatos) can make music more interesting.

96834AC273894B95B4B0045AF4F58A89.description: Demonstrate balance between repetition and variety in a melody.

3AA8A7CA59A2400DAC2E0E904D1BB8A9.description: Create and manipulate melodic phrases using repetition and variety.

A8DC4FB640564887B66F73EB705E6A09.description: Investigate ways that variety can add interest and repetition can hold a musical piece together.

BBB7244A69FC46978740621127D7681F.description: Play rhythmic ostinatos inspired by music of various cultures, identifying how repetition and variety are achieved.

A535366C6CD041039712AE84DDEA7D31.description: Investigate how phrases in vocal and instrumental music can be repeated or contrasted with other phrases to create larger structural units (e.g., call/response, question/answer, rounds).

C0CF6B5E633B4C2DB38FD8CA388E8271.description: Identify repetition and variety in own music and the music of others, and analyze how it is achieved.

2A828EBD1831435AB341024D4D3317DC.description: Demonstrate how musicians and composers use principles of composition such as repetition and variety as tools to organize the elements of music (i.e., rhythm, melody/pitch, dynamics, timbre/tone colour, texture).

F0BFC0C274FD474C82B08173B17679DC.description: Use inquiry in music to extend understanding of the composition principles of repetition and variety: Pose questions to guide inquiry into how elements of music can be manipulated to create repetition and variety (e.g., How can we demonstrate repetition and variety using rhythm? How can we manipulate texture to create repetition and variety? How are we using repetition and variety in our techno or hip hop beats and lyrics?), Experiment with voice and instruments to explore the inquiry questions, Collaborate with peers to document the inquiry process (e.g., traditional and/or invented notation, audio or video recording). and Rehearse and perform to share inquiry results with others.

D7D87D20037A4F1AB2B831EA7F563620.description: Investigate and manipulate elements of music and principles of composition including repetition and variety

2D4BD7375A62449F9ABDC9A9F0BF0760.description: Collaborate on the identification and evaluation of performance criteria such as clarity, unity, and expression.

9A6562796477401786A0F6B5D318E9EE.description: Prepare, rehearse, present, and assess own music performances.

7BDA6332BE054F9B9CEBE149ABCE37C0.description: Change the feel, style, or add another part to an existing piece of music.

54F0775CF6EA49339DD5820137B5C4F1.description: Sing, play, and create music that demonstrates a variety of techniques and styles.

76C02B2422B1409B9327028EC6B83396.description: Distinguish among diverse voice types, styles, and forms of vocal expression.

2A1B3E6D623B46EA8BD3EF21A80D20E1.description: Recognize, and be sensitive to, ways that voices change with age and musical experience.

62C0213A302A4B929C9DA82A914306AA.description: Extend skills in singing and expand ability to sing harmony and parts.

542D694EC1714F2986A94770B9C2348D.description: Experiment with voice and instruments by creating a wide variety of sounds and sound patterns

6EEC952FFB494DD38B9D653F01B85AB7.description: Demonstrate increased skills and abilities in the use of voice and instruments.

27E15224998B459E89B57A90484922D2.description: Describe how the drama conveys ideas about identity, and how the drama might be refined.

15A493E379044C98A3616D4F8231AA44.description: Confer with peers to decide how work will be documented and shared.

FC479B8CC6D042F192CB4338276251E0.description: Demonstrate a willingness to negotiate, accept the ideas of others, and work toward consensus in dramatic work.

3B2B854DED224AFCBEB07AFD93912E7E.description: Use symbol to represent ideas about identity and to convey meaning in drama.

617BA18E24964276A5671BEB359DA25C.description: Examine ways of creating contrast in a drama (e.g., movement/stillness, sound/silence, and light/darkness).

6FDD144A954841D689287298A56D90D3.description: Understand how conflict and tension can impel a response or action in a drama.

16381EC44CA24911B5998977F91C5FF7.description: Recognize that dramas, and episodes within dramas, have focus; and help to identify and maintain that focus.

4B32CD2F8A58486CA70D7C5EDDEFC01B.description: Propose options and choose from among many possible drama strategies to help direct the course and quality of the work.

75DA167B6239437682A0CC78A8A34AA3.description: Contribute ideas to the topic, focus, and development of the drama.

328A39260DE34D589390B2CAD29582F2.description: Use inquiry in drama to extend understanding about identity and how it is influenced: • Generate questions to guide inquiry in drama (e.g., What if we were to discover that we had suddenly switched identities with other people or creatures?). and Use the Internet and other sources (e.g., print, digital, community) to research and gain information and ideas that will contribute to the authenticity and significance of the drama.

2DAB608E8FC945A4BEABEECF92662F48.description: Collaborate on a drama that expresses ideas about identity and how it is influenced (e.g., factors such as pop culture, cultural heritage, peer groups, personal and family interests, gender).

15AEAF9F2A16473088434D75BF777894.description: Assess and evaluate use of tension, conflict, and symbol in own work, and apply conclusions to new work.

2026A4BF7B9F45D48DEC96106B934ABC.description: Describe how ideas expressed through symbol, for example, in dramas and collective creations relate to own lives, cultures, and society.

2E25240B64B84DA1893F75E8F21DE1D5.description: Suggest ways to refine (e.g., their focus) and improve the work

D915200DCB7444C9AB447329B31832AC.description: Use the language and vocabulary of drama when reflecting on the work.

8143193E1DED4FCFB6786BCD0D10AA77.description: Suggest various ways to use symbols in the drama work.

12418411C8BC4D60AD91D0DF097F3004.description: Suggest various ways to create a sense of tension or conflict in the drama work.

2EE12222F93F477AB715974074A7275C.description: Support the focus during pair and group work, improvisations, and the development of dramatic episodes.

3A1C3A7B6A6C4069960AD8B554994CEF.description: Select and use focus, tension, conflict, and symbol to convey ideas.

1ABCE38599CF4D489B5E8AB18E72E39B.description: Draw on own life experience and imagination when speaking and representing ideas in role.

75C79A75C5A845EF8655A0280A960702.description: Reflect on, and explain, how the various roles function and express different identities within the work.

7E1951A724614426B293465C0A91A85D.description: Demonstrate a willingness to take a risk in developing new roles.

E349D507AB31411FA2136F13C66E5815.description: Assume different types of roles and fictional identities in drama work.

67017B7656554A3A8FEF141F22C2A678.description: Use language to achieve dramatic purposes when speaking and writing in role.

F11E1BE53C4A48B9ADD0B058D2108F49.description: Sustain belief in own roles and in the roles assumed by others.

5E6F14B296CD4733BBAF4A6977DC7713.description: Initiate and develop roles in selected drama forms (e.g., contextual, improv, puppetry, radio drama).

995434F219ED4F339EC8B7DE866B82DE.description: Determine effectiveness of transitions and form in own dance compositions.

FD22A2C106844E0182F91B6EF880F877.description: Experiment with the use of focus and apply to own work (i.e., where in space one’s gaze is directed).

B5EC358CABE04EEC87DA3A5DC71E37AB.description: Apply understanding of form as an organizing structure in dance

5392318480254F37B7AB4DFE5BA295E0.description: Explore various forms in own dance compositions (e.g., AABB, ABA, ABACA).

B3D918E8AA194120855F57FE21A7EF40.description: Demonstrate expressive transitional movements between dance phrases and sequences.

9908021CB1474E899887362AFB1EB9EB.description: Investigate and demonstrate different ways of sequencing and developing movements and phrases.

0299FCD8C01D4FA3B13C8A21A809077D.description: Shape dance compositions using various choreographic forms (e.g., ABA).

53F91BCA30F94B7A80339ECF51DA7BF1.description: Explore and apply biomechanical concepts and principles of force production, force absorption, and resistance (see grade 6 physical education curriculum outcome 6.7) during warmups and dance compositions.

40FBFC1F0EBD41A3B80EA809051B96C9.description: Create with own bodies various volumes and pathways on the floor and through space using repetition and contrast.

BF8804050ACA489F8396108BAF71E896.description: Extend repertoire of actions for expressive purposes and to demonstrate repetition and contrast.

CBA2F30A2DFA450CBCFE8B0833832598.description: Show how movements can be initiated from the centre or the periphery of the body and incorporated into dance.

DB71D058D2A34AA2B355E27D58A91F7E.description: Use inquiry questions to guide investigations into the elements of dance and the principles of repetition and contrast (e.g., How could we use repetition and contrast in the dance sequences to show how people often follow pop culture trends?).

934B145239934527B2752AE510944F00.description: Demonstrate ways that contrast creates interest or variety in dance

1A8F1DF5776940E982963EFF91B490E1.description: Analyze, discuss, and explore through movement, the principles of repetition and contrast in dance.

62C05D2345664D9CBB2FBFD6845E665F.description: Investigate and demonstrate choreographic principles using the elements of actions, body, relationships, dynamics, and space.

B6CC2A08CE844B57A490FC5C57286715.description: Investigate and manipulate elements of dance and principles of composition including repetition and contrast.

B32B20C263AD498A807B73EDE00606A1.description: Reflect upon choices made during dance-making process.

4635C160C172405BAA863B10188F51E2.description: Reflect on how movement and dance elements can be organized to convey meaning in dance (e.g., What messages or ideas does our movement or dance communicate to an audience about identity?).

F80D59D145ED42F783B40208CB75CA61.description: Demonstrate self-awareness in decision making about own movement selections.

CC003710DAE14E89BE6FA37EDB1F809E.description: Investigate how a single idea can be developed in many ways and directions (e.g., How could we represent in movement the idea of an individual feeling isolated or excluded from a peer group?).

06AD3BD809164EDC9F467BF2D0AC78D4.description: Use inquiry in dance to extend understanding of identity (e.g., examine how pop culture trends influence youth identities): Generate key questions to guide inquiry in dance (e.g., How could we represent through dance the unique identities of different peer groups?), Summarize and focus knowledge of topic to determine information needs, Generate additional relevant questions for deeper exploration, Use the Internet and other relevant sources (e.g., print, digital, community) to research and gather ideas for dance-making, Use the dance-making process to explore the central questions and ideas (e.g., How could we show through movement that each peer group has a distinct identity? How can we use hip hop or other dance forms to communicate our individual or community identities?), Expand on dance and movement ideas in reflective records such as journals, blogs, and video or audio recordings, Keep a record of dance phrases using invented and/or traditional notation symbols, and video where possible, to explore, record, and reconstruct movements. and Reflect, analyze, and make connections between the original topic or inquiry question and subsequent dance explorations.

B966FC5D3FE240A48E325C2E520150D8.description: Create dance compositions that express ideas about identity and how it is influenced (e.g., factors such as pop culture, cultural heritage, peer groups, personal and family interests, gender).

4C6A6D6C81FA4F2BB5CDFCEA7FA813F2.description: Creative/Productive (CP) - Children will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music, and visual art.
